text: HIGH FUEL, FERTILIZER PRICES TO LEAD TO
label: BODY

text: FEWER PLANTED CORN ACRES IN 2006, USDA SAYS
label: BODY

text: Washington, March 31, 2006 – The high cost of fuel and fertilizer is leading U.S. farmers to switch from corn to
label: BODY

text: less input-intensive crops such as soybeans in 2006, according to the Prospective Plantings report released today by
label: BODY

text: the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s National Agricultural Statistics Service (NASS).
label: BODY

text: Producers plan to plant 78 million acres of corn in 2006, down 5 percent from 2005. Meanwhile, they
label: BODY

text: intend to plant a record-high 76.9 million acres of soybeans, up 7 percent. For all wheat, NASS expects planted area
label: BODY

text: to remain almost unchanged from last season at 57.1 million acres, despite a major drop in durum wheat acres.
label: BODY

text: Cotton area is expected to rise 3 percent, to 14.6 million acres.
label: BODY

text: Expected corn acreage is down in most states, the NASS report shows. Illinois expects the largest decline
label: BODY

text: with 700,000 fewer acres, a 6 percent drop from last year’s record level. The only states showing increases from
label: BODY

text: last year are North Dakota, Arizona and Utah, while Minnesota remains unchanged from a year ago.
label: BODY

text: For soybeans, NASS reports expected acreage increases in all growing areas except the Atlantic Coast and
label: BODY

text: in the southern Great Plains. The largest increase is in North Dakota, with a 41 percent jump to a record-high 4.15
label: BODY

text: million acres. Significant growth in soybean acreage is also expected across the Corn Belt, including Illinois, with a
label: BODY

text: 6 percent increase to 10.1 million acres, and Indiana, with a 9 percent jump to 5.9 million acres.
label: BODY

text: All wheat planted area is expected to total 57.1 million acres, down slightly from 2005. Winter wheat
label: BODY

text: acreage is up 2 percent, while spring wheat is down 1 percent. Intended durum wheat planted area is 1.83 million
label: BODY

text: acres, down 34 percent from the previous year. If realized, this will be the lowest durum wheat acreage since 1961.
label: BODY

text: U.S. cotton producers intend to plant 14.6 million acres in 2006, 3 percent more than last year. Upland
label: BODY

text: cotton area is expected to total 14.3 million acres, also up 3 percent. American-Pima cotton growers intend to
label: BODY

text: increase their plantings 24 percent from 2005, to a record 334,000 acres.
label: BODY

text: NASS reports that U.S. acreage planted to oats will increase 2 percent in 2006, while dry edible bean acres
label: BODY

text: are up 3 percent and sugar beet acres are up 6 percent. Sorghum and hay acreage are virtually unchanged.
label: BODY

text: Meanwhile, barley acreage is expected to decline 5 percent from last year, with rice down 12 percent, peanuts down
label: BODY

text: 16 percent and sunflower down 19 percent.
label: BODY

text: The Prospective Plantings report provides the first official estimates of U.S. farmers’ planting intentions
label: BODY

text: for 2006. NASS’s acreage estimates are based on surveys conducted during the first two weeks of March among a
label: BODY

text: sample of more than 87,000 farm operators across the United States.
label: BODY

text: Prospective Plantings, along with all other NASS reports, is available online at www.nass.usda.gov.
label: BODY
